I updated that in the most recent pull request that i’m waiting for you to approve
having access to users that they have previously collaborated with's email addresses makes that easier
the idea with contact information was that when a user creates a meeting, they have an invite screen where they type in email addresses for people they want to invite.

the form as it is allows the user to enter a new username and not a new email address. this changes the local.email to empty string, effectively meaning they either a) can't login or b) anybody else who accidentally does the same thing will be locked out, since there will be several users who's local.email = '' but only one who has the right password
I thought that was what we were going to do anyway the email for login can be changed and keep seperate but what contact information is going to be needed

the 'local' property on the User object is specific to passport-local strategy to login. that should never get changed. if we want to store user contact info or add email addresses to the profile, we should create a 'contact info' property on the user object.

The way I'm envisioning the flow for the app will be as follows. This can be paired down or simplified as needed. It only reflects what I personally would like the app to do. Again, comments and criticism are welcome. This is a work in progress and is meant only to get the ball rolling. 

*Edit: Sorry for the wall of text. This is also on Trello, for posterity.*

Creating a meeting
---

1. After selecting the "create new meeting" button on the dashboard, the user will be greeted by the "Creating a Meeting page" (first wireframe)
1. The user will provide a name for the new meeting.
1. They will then provide an orienting timezone for the meeting (this should default to the meeting creator's timezone)
1. They will then provide the proposed dates for the meeting.
1. Finally, they will click submit to create the meeting with the chosen parameters. This will take the creator to the next step:

Entering in available times
---

*This screen will appear the same for both the second overall step of creating a meeting as well as for the invited meeting participants*

1. This screen will have a vertical time line for each proposed day of the meeting, set by the creator in the previous step. **Note:** This timeline will be in the user's timezone by default, but there should also be a drop down that can change the timezone view.
1. The user will click/touch and drag on the timeline to provide their available times.
1. When the user is happy with their selections, they will click the 'submit times' button, which will upload their selections to the server.

Inviting New Users
---

1. The meeting creator will add the people she wants to meet with. It would be nice if the creator can choose from a list of previous collaborators, and if the person isn't on the list, the creator can send an invite to that person.
1. When the user is satisfied with her participant list, she will click submit.
1. Participants will be notified of the meeting and given a link to the meeting. If the user isn't logged in, she will be asked to do so.
1. If the user doesn't have an account yet, she will be asked to create one. After she is registered, she will be taken to the meeting she was invited to.

your node modules folder will live on your local copy but not get uploaded to git because it's listed in that file, so don't worry if it doesn't show up on the git repo page.
yeah, that makes sense.

yup, the node modules file is necessary. the json is what npm install looks at to see which modules are needed, so to avoid clogging the repo, the /node_modules folder is listed on the .gitignore file, which tells git which files to not upload/download every time.

also, i installed the node modules inside my repo, so there's a node_modules folder in there. this is the right way to do that, correct? and the json is there to mark the required modules without clogging up the repo with the actual files and folders?

Hi @QuincyLarson ! I'm on it!
Hi everyone, thanks for expressing interest in this project. Please take a moment to familiarize yourself with WorldTimeBuddy.com and when2meet.com

Hi everyone, we have a requested application. It’s not for a nonprofit - it’s for us to use internally. It will be challenging, but could be built in stages, by several campers or pairs of campers.

#The users#
Free Code Camp’s nonprofit project team and Twitch Live Code team.

#The Problem#
We frequently need to schedule meetings with campers and nonprofit stakeholders. These people are located all around the world in different time zones. We need to figure out each person’s availability so we can find an optimal time to meet.

#The Current Solution#
We use a tool called WorldTimeBuddy.com to look at times across time zones.
We use a tool called when2meet.com to figure out which times work best for all participants.
But when2meet doesn’t localize to the individual users' timezones.
So we need a tool that combines these functionalities.

This tool could go on to become a major open source project, and would look excellent in your portfolio. If you’re interested in building this, PM me. Thanks!
